labeled_passages.text: What artificial sweeteners should you avoid?
labeled_passages.title: What to Know About Aspartame
labeled_passages.author: WebMD Editorial Contributors
sources: The BMJ : “ Aspartame and Its Effects On Health. ”
Cancer Research UK: “ Aspartame and artificial sweeteners - helping or hindering weight loss? ”
Current Diabetes Review : “ Aspartame: Should Individuals with Type II Diabetes be Taking It? ”
European Food Safety Authority: “ Aspartame. ”
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services: “ What is the relationship Between Aspartame Consumption and Health? ”

Nutrients: “Aspartame—True or False? Narrative Review of Safety Analysis of General Use in Products.”
The British Journal of Nutrition: “The effect of aspartame and sucralose intake on body weight measures and blood metabolites: role of their form (solid and/or liquid) of ingestion.”
The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition: “Consumption of caffeinated and artificially sweetened soft drinks is associated with risk of early menarche.”
Journal of Nutrition & Intermediary Metabolism : “Disruption of redox homeostasis in liver function and activation of apoptosis on consumption of aspartame in folate deficient rat model.”
Research in Nursing & Health: “Neurobehavioral Effects of Aspartame Consumption.”

U.S. Food & Drug Administration: “Aspartame and Other Sweeteners in Food.”

Neuropsychopharmacology: “Tardive dyskinesia exacerbated after ingestion of phenylalanine by schizophrenic patients.”

European Food Safety Authority: “Aspartame.”

labeled_passages.text: But for all their benefits, some artificial sweeteners pose risks. Talk to your doctor if you have health concerns.
labeled_passages.title: Artificial Sweeteners and Diabetes: What to Know
labeled_passages.author: Nichole Owens
sources: Amy Roark MS, RDN, CSSD, LD, CDCES, Northside Hospital Diagnostic Clinic, Gainesville, Georgia
Mayo Clinic: “ Artificial sweeteners: Any effect on blood sugar? ”
Massachusetts General Hospital: “ Sugar Substitutes: What You Should Know. ”
Cleveland Clinic: “Carbohydrates,” “ This is why artificial sweeteners are bad for you, ” “ Do You Need to Cut Out Aspartame? ”
American Heart Association: “Sugar 101, ” “ Food Packaging Claims. ”
Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health: “ Are sugar alcohols healthier alternative sweeteners? ”
UCLA: “ How safe are sugar alcohols? ”
Johns Hopkins Medicine: “ Facts About Sugar and Sugar Substitutes. ”

UC Davis: “Nutrition & Health Info Sheets for Health Professionals: Nonnutririve Sweeteners. ”
FDA: “ Types of Food Ingredients, ” “ Changes to the Nutrition Facts Label, ” “ Aspartame and other sweeteners in food. ”

Nutrients : “ Effect of Non-Nutritive Sweeteners on the Gut Microbiota, ” “ Long-term Consumption of Sucralose Induces Hepatic Insulin Resistance through Extracellular Signal-Related Kinase ½ Dependent Pathway. ”
American Diabetes Association: “Sweeteners and Desserts: Sugar and Other Sweeteners.”

labeled_passages.text: There are six artificial sweeteners that the FDA says are safe for most people: aspartame, acesulfame potassium (Ace-K), sucralose , neotame, advantame, and saccharin.
labeled_passages.title: What to Know About Aspartame
labeled_passages.author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

labeled_passages.text: Yes, they can. Artificial sweeteners are just as sweet — and sometimes, up to 700 times sweeter — than regular sugar, but they have no calories and don’t affect your blood sugar (glucose). While sugar is absorbed into your bloodstream and sent to your cells to be turned into energy, artificial sweeteners stay in your digestive tract until they pass in your stool or urine.
